Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2010
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship for FY 2010. The fellowship supports a research and training plan entitled "Network and statistical analyses of animal social complexity" for Tina Wey. The host institution for this research is University of California Davis and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Andy Sih.

Social structure, the pattern of social interaction among members of a group, is thought to play an important role in determining how individual traits influence mating success. However, a comprehensive understanding of how social structure influences mating success is lacking. Social network analysis offers a quantitative approach to measuring complex patterns of interaction. This project uses a large behavioral dataset on experimentally manipulated, replicated social groups of stream water striders (Aquarius remigis) to examine the effect of social network structure on mating success. Specifically, the project addresses the following questions: 1) What are the relative effects of social network traits at multiple stages on mating success? 2) How does group network structure emerge from individual traits and influence reproductive success? 3) How do network dynamics influence mating success, and how do individuals respond to network change? 4) How does environmental variation alter the relationship between network structure and individual success? This work addresses properties of real systems (complex interactions at multiple levels and temporal dynamics) that have been difficult to analyze and is producing a predictive framework and analytical methodology that can be broadly applied to many social systems.

Training objectives include developing skills in network and statistical analysis, computer programming, and scientific outreach. Project goals include developing and disseminating new analytical tools needed to study animal social complexity, while fostering interdisciplinary collaboration between experts in behavioral ecology, network analysis, and statistics. This project advances our understanding of mating success, social complexity and evolution. Expected outcomes include a workshop and free online tutorial designed to teach behavioral ecologists basic social network analysis that can be applied to diverse questions and systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project looked at how individual and social group characteristics influenced social structure and mating outcomes in stream water striders (Aquarius remigis). Intuitively, we know that social interactions can influence what happens to individuals, including their mating success, but it is often difficult to measure this. Detailed observations of animals in experimental groupings allow us to describe and study networks of different interactions. In water striders, more active and aggressive males usually do better in terms of having higher mating success. However, male aggression is generally bad for females, and overly aggressive males can reduce their own and everybody else’s mating success. We were interested in how males of different aggression levels influenced their networks of mating interactions with females and networks of competition with other males.

In many social networks, more similar individual tend to interact more with each other, which can influence network formation and outcomes. Thus we wanted to test the ideas that more promiscuous males tended to mate with more promiscuous females, and that more active and aggressive males tended to compete with other males that were also more active and aggressive. Contrary to our expectations, there was no relationship between male and female promiscuity when there are equal numbers of males and females, and when there are many more males (creating more competition between males), it appeared that more promiscuous males may even mate with less promiscuous females. This suggests that some males are doing especially well (and others are doing especially poorly) when there is more male competition. Other analyses suggest that more active and aggressive males are, as expected, competing with other males that are more active and aggressive. When there are highly aggressive males present, these males have a strong effect on patterns of male aggression, with most aggressive interactions focused around these central males, and less aggressive interactions among other males. Many analyses are ongoing, and we are also asking how stable patterns of mating and aggressive interactions are over time, and if certain males are better at modifying their interaction with females or other males in different situations.

In addition, the project has resulted in short undergraduate and graduate seminars about potential application of social network analysis to animal behavior, intended for students just starting to get interested in using this type of approach and methods for their own research. These seminars consist of lectures that can be presented in one or two class periods, and a short (one- to two-hour) hands-on workshop intended as a tutorial to walk students through useful features in one popular and user-friendly social network analysis program. The lectures have been presented multiple times over the two years of the project, and the full workshop was presented in the second year for an undergraduate course and resulted in a student-led study and publication. The seminars have been modified for each presentation, and I plan to continue to modify and develop the materials to make them more useful and comprehensive for interested students at different levels of study.


Last Modified: 05/30/2013
Modified by: Tina W Wey

In many social networks, more similar individual tend to interact more with each other, which can influence network formation and outcomes. Thus we wanted to test the ideas that more promiscuous males tended to mate with more promiscuous females, and that more active and aggressive males tended to compete with other males that were also more active and aggressive.
